text.p: These are the main stories in Latvian newspapers on Monday. Prepared for Reuters by the Co-operation Fund. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:

- The leader of the Fatherland & Freedom party, Maris Griblats, announced that a compromise on choosing two of the privatisation agency's directors through an open competition is nothing but avoiding transparency in the privatisation process and making it only partly democratic.
- There was a military review in Liepaja on April 12, devoted to the fifth anniversary of Latvian navy forces. The navy has 17 warships, of which two are mine sweepers.
- President Guntis Ulmanis arrived in France on a two-day official visit, whose goal is to draw attention to security issues in the Baltic region.

- Foreign Minister Valdis Birkavs anounced on his return from a central Asian tour that his visit was a success. He said that Latvia, Russia and Uzbekistan may create a joint work group to expanding the transit corridor and make it safer. Around 1/3 of Uzbekistan's cotton exports goes through Latvian harbours.
- Beginning today, shares of Latvia's Savings Bank will be available in public auction.
- Foreign Minister Valdis Birkavs announced at a press-conference that Latvia is ready to sign a border treaty with Russia at any time.

- Finance Minister Roberts Zile said in an interview that he believes tax rates in Latvia are at a normal level except for social tax. The minister regards free economic zones as one of instruments to increase the country's GDP.
- The state revenue service plans to invest 22.7 million lats over the five coming years to increase the state income.
